metadata.title: Enhancing the permeability and abrasion resistance of concrete using colloidal nano-SiO2 oxide and spraying nanosilicon practices

Enhancing the permeability and abrasion resistance of concrete using colloidal nano-SiO2 oxide and spraying nanosilicon practices

h i g h l i g h t s
Reducing permeability and enhance the water resistance properties of concrete. Spraying nanosilicon to surface and treatment in water-diluted nano-SiO2 oxide. Comparing mechanical & microstructure properties of treated and untreated concrete. Nano-SiO2 as an additive after preparing concrete and during curing process.
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 20 October 2016 Received in revised form 20 March 2017 Accepted 9 April 2017
Keywords: Nano-SiO2 Nanosilicon spray Concrete treatment Permeability Abrasion resistance SEM
a b s t r a c t
By protecting concrete from penetration of aggressive chemicals, low permeability is one of the most important contributory factors to the concrete’s durability. In this paper the effects of nano-SiO2 particles on concrete permeability are studied through employing the technique of spraying nanosilicon and treatment in the water-diluted nano-SiO2 oxide. To this end, some mechanical and microstructure properties of concrete are investigated. The results show that the compression strength and the resistance of specimens to water penetration are significantly increased, whether in the mixtures cured in the colloidal solution or those being sprayed with nano-SiO2. The minute dimensions of these particles allow them to penetrate up to a particular depth in a concrete panel. Hence, through improvement of concrete panel nanostructures, these particles participate in the completion of the hydration process, which in turn leads to a reduction in their permeability and development of a protective layer, and therefore the increase of bulk concrete panel durability. The experiment’s outcomes also develop thorough understanding of the effects of nano-SiO2 as an additive material after preparing the concrete and during the curing process.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
In recent years, there has been a growing interest in nanotechnological products, processes and applications due to their wide potential benefits [1]. In concrete technology, some nanoparticles, such as SiO2, ZnO2, Al2O3, CuO, CaCo3, Fe2O3, and TiO2 have been widely employed by many researchers to enhance the quality of cementitious materials, by modifying the microstructural, mechanical and durability properties of concrete or mortar [2– 10]. When nanoparticles are integrated with cement-based building materials, the new materials can possess some outstanding
properties. During previous studies, Nano-SiO2 has been one of the most commonly used materials in comparison with the other nanomaterials [11–16]. However, the literature has been mainly focused on the study of the properties of concrete or mortar mixtures containing these nanoparticles as additives, and other techniques of treatments have not been adequately investigated. Qing et al. [11] showed that in comparison to adding silica fume, nano-SiO2 influences compressive strengths of hardened cement paste and bond strengths of the paste-aggregate interface in a different way. Incorporating nano-SiO2 into cement has stronger effects on cement properties compared to silica fume, especially at an early age. Jalal et al. [12,17] investigated the effects of micro SiO2 and nanoparticles on the rheological, mechanical, durability and microstructural characteristics of high-performance self-
compacting concrete. The results indicates that using micro and nano-silica can have a remarkable influence on improving the various properties of concrete [18]. The authors also investigated the split tensile strength along with the rheological, thermal, transport and microstructural properties of self-compacting concrete (SCC) containing low volume fly ash and TiO2 nanoparticles. They showed TiO2 nano-powder improves the microstructure of concrete by shifting the distributed pores to finer and less harmful pores [19]. The results of their study also showed that mechanical and transport properties improves in the mixtures containing admixtures especially blend of silica nanoparticles and silica fume [20].
Madandoust et al. [5] studied the effects of the addition of nano-SiO2, nano-Fe2O3 and nano-CuO particles on the microstructural and durability performance of self-compacting mortar containing fly ash. According to their results, the properties of fresh and hardened samples are affected considerably by the nanoparticle ratio in the cement mortars. In their tests, the slump flow diameter increased by 4.2% and V-funnel flow time decreased by 13%. The specimen containing nano-SiO2 had the highest strength compared to other specimens. For example, with 5% cement replacement, the compressive strength increases 18% at the age of 90 days. The addition of nano-SiO2 also improves resistance to water permeability [14,16]. Naji et al. [15], discovered that curing in the limewater can reduce the strength of control concrete, but curing the specimens containing SiO2 nanoparticles in saturated limewater causes a more rapid setting time as well as higher values of strength and resistance to water absorption. Findings from the literature indicate that the nano scale SiO2 behaves not only as a filler to improve microstructure but also as an activator to promote the pozzolanic reaction [1]. Nano-SiO2 particles enhance the density of cement paste in three ways: as a pozzolan, a core for forming C-S-H gel, and as a nano-scale filler for filling nano-scale pores. All these three mechanisms can act cooperatively at the same time [7].
The concrete durability critically influences the service life of the concrete structure [21], and consequently its life cycle costs [22]. In addition, concrete permeability is one of the most important parameters influencing the durability of concrete and its performance [23,24]. The most important factor in steel-reinforced concrete corrosion is diffusion of destructive ions to the concrete. Hence, reduction in permeability of the outer layer of the concrete can prevent these ions from reaching to reinforced-concrete [25] Given that permeability reduction in the back part of reinforcedconcrete has no role in the prevention of its corrosion, focus on the decrease of permeability in the outer layer and reinforcedconcrete cover can lead to a reduction in material cost [26–29]. A water permeability test shows that for concretes with similar 28- day strength, the incorporation of nano-SiO2 particles can improve resistance to water permeability in concretes [30,31]. As Mehta et al. [32] reported, the permeability coefficient in day 6 is nearly 100 times higher than day 24. Moreover, many investigations on the abrasion resistance of concrete shows that it is strongly influenced by surface finishing techniques, compressive strength, aggregate properties, curing method, and testing conditions [1,2]. It is also demonstrated by previous studies that curing methods have an significant impact on the abrasion resistance of mortar or concrete [3]. In general, appropriate curing practices are proven to remarkably promote the abrasion resistance of concrete. Although some great advantages of nano-SiO2 as an effective additive and partial replacement of cement have been investigated in the literature, their other practical applications in concrete technology have not been yet thoroughly surveyed.
Considering high costs of these materials compared with the other ingredients of concrete, this research study is an attempt to develop an economical method to employ nano-SiO2 particles in
order to reduce permeability and enhance the water resistance of concrete. This work is concentrated on evaluating the effect of curing concrete by colloidal nano-SiO2 and nanosilicon spray, on water permeability and abrasion resistance. The nanoparticles’ transfer with water or sprayer from concrete surface to its body is investigated through measuring permeability and abrasion changes. During the tests, permeability depth was frequently measured after applying water pressure. The experimental tests of slump, density, compressive strength, permeability, abrasion, and SEMwere conducted in this study. The study shows how using curing concrete in colloidal nano-SiO2 oxide and spraying nanosilicon practices to the surface of the concrete, can result in significant improvement in permeability and abrasion resistance. The findings can also contribute to determining the optimal nano-SiO2 proportions.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: For all samples, type II Ordinary Portland cement conforming to the requirements of the ASTM C150 was used [33]. The physical characteristics and chemical compositions of the Portland cementash are summarized in Table 1. Moreover, coarse aggregate size number 57 (2.5–4.75 mm) was designated, according to the ASTM C33 [34]. Also, fine aggregate meets the specifications mentioned in the ASTM C33 standard [35]. To increase workability in all mixtures, superplasticizer was added, which was a poly carboxylatebased high range water reducer (HRWR) with a density of between 1.06 and 1.08 g/cm3 (at 20 C) [21]. The specific gravity of the expander additive was 1200 kg/m3. To produce sample mixtures with different properties in this research, various ratios of water to cementation materials are considered. SiO2 nanoparticles with an average particle size of 50 nm were used.

sections.heading: 2.2. Mixture proportions
sections.text:
A total of 4 mixtures containing 144 samples in 150 150 150 mm cubes were designed with the same materials and different water/binder ratios. Half of the samples were supposed to have 28 days of colloidal nano-SiO2 curing with three different nano-SiO2 contents (12%, 8%, and 4%). Meanwhile, some cubic specimens were kept in tap water as control samples. The other samples were sprayed with nanosilicon in two different contents (25% and 50%) at three different times; i) immediately after casting the mixture in the mold ii) after 1 h and 45 min iii) after 4 h of casting. For each mixture, 18 cubic samples were made. Nano-SiO2 did not have any effect on the abrasion resistance and just influenced the cement paste. Therefore, in order to achieve
the direct effect of nano-SiO2 on abrasion, the other 72 samples were made by cement paste containing water (19 kg), cement (54.7 kg) with the constant ratio of water to cement (35%), and expander additive in 120 80 50 mm cubes. Details of the mixture proportion are presented in Table 2.
It should be noted that all samples were made in the same condition. The fine and coarse aggregates were mixed for 1 min at a normal mixing speed of 80 rpm. Water and superplasticizer were then added, followed by addition of cement and all were mixed for 3 min. Afterward, the mixtures were poured into molds to be prepared for various tests, and curing continued until the 28-day age at 24 C temperature.

sections.heading: 2.3.1. Fresh concrete tests
sections.text: The slump test for fresh concrete was conducted in conformity with the standard procedures given by the ASTM C143-78 [36]. The slump test was carried out to evaluate the workability of concrete. The density of the mixtures was obtained by weighing the fresh concrete in a standard mold with the specific weight and volume in accordance with the ASTM C 138-81 standard [37].

sections.heading: 2.3.2. Hardened concrete tests
sections.text:
Fresh concrete was cast into 150 150 150 mm cubes for compressive strength, permeability, and abrasion tests. Each test result was the average of three samples’ test results. A day after casting, samples were demolded and kept in water until the testing day.
2.3.2.1. Compressive strength test. The compressive strength test was conducted by using a hydraulic testing machine under the loading rate of 1350 N/Sec for 28 days of curing in accordance with the BS1881 Standard [38].
2.3.2.2. Permeability resistance test. The permeability test was also carried out in 28 days by following the DIN 1048 standard [39] procedure under the loading rate of 300 Kpa for 24 h, as it is shown in Fig. 1. The samples were then split to measure water permeability depth. Every specimen cured in colloidal nano-SiO2 was tested at the same time with the corresponding control sample to ensure that the testing condition is similar. However, the samples sprayed with nanosilicon were tested at two different times. In this work, the Enhancement Factor (EF) was defined to demonstrate the difference between permeability depth in colloidal nano-SiO2 cured samples and plain water cured samples by Eq.1:

2.3.2.3. Abrasion test. Since the abrasion resistance of the cement paste is very low compared to the aggregates, this project intended to investigate the effect of nanosilica on the enhancement of the wear resistance of concrete. Since nanosilica had no impact on the enhancement of wear resistance of concrete, stiff cement paste samples were used instead of concrete samples. This way, direct effects of nanosilica on the abrasion resistance of cement paste were measured.
The abrasion test on cement paste samples was performed according to EN 1338 Standard [40]. First, the standard tank was filled with river sand with the size distribution of 1.4 to 1.18 mm. The samples were then placed on a concrete preservatives jaw. Afterwards, the machine measurement was set on zero. The specimens were under 1000 rounds per 13 s rotation. 2.3.2.4. Scanning electron microscope (SEM). The scanning electron microscope (SEM) test was carried out in order to investigate the microstructural properties of the specimens. The SEM tests were done on the pieces at the distance of 1 cm below the surface of the main sample. The specimens were broken and converted into small fragments. Afterward, hydration was stopped by pure alcohol. The tiny particles then were sprayed in the SBC-12 small particles sputtering apparatus to create specimens [8,41].

sections.heading: 3.1. Slump
sections.text: Table 3 shows four slump classes obtained from various mixtures. As it is shown in the table, the least slump value was related to the class D mixture, which shows the higher workability of this mixture compared to the other concrete mixtures.

sections.heading: 3.2. Density
sections.text: Table 3 shows the density of the control samples. Results indicate that depending on the aggregate size and water/cement ratio, the density varied from 2410 to 2442 kg/m3. It is noteworthy that the early age density was reduced with the increase of the water/ binder ratio. From the table, it can be seen that the mixture with lower density (2410) has a higher water/binder ratio (79%) in comparison with the other mixtures. In fact, there is a linear relation between water/binder and reduction of density. The reason is that heavier aggregates are replaced by water. It should be noted that the densities obtained from the other mixtures were almost equal to the mixture A.

sections.heading: 3.3. Compressive strength
sections.text:
With regard to compressive strength, approximately equal proportions of 380–385 kg/cm2 were obtained from four mixtures.
This shows that the techniques of curing concrete (colloidal nano-SiO2 oxide and spraying nanosilicon practices) mainly affect the surface of the concrete and have no considerable influence on the compressive strength.

sections.heading: 3.4. Permeability
sections.text:
Table 4 shows results of water permeability depth in samples cured in colloidal nano-SiO2. According to the results shown in Table 4, the minimum and maximum values of EF occurred in the environment with 12% colloidal nano-SiO2. Therefore, there is no significant difference in the results for curing conditions with colloidal nano-SiO2 contents of 4, 8, and 12 percent. On the other hand, in all samples cured in plain water, water permeability depth in concrete decreased. This enhancement between colloidal nanoSiO2 and plain water cured samples, represented by EF, varies between 5% and 31%. It is noteworthy that for concrete with higher permeability, a drop in the permeability ratio is more remarkable. Generally, the mean value of EF in experiments is 14% and is not lower than 10% for 76% of the results, as shown in Figs. 1 and 3. Previous studies also showed the positive effects of nanoparticles on the permeability of the cementitious materials. Although in this study the nanoparticles were just used in the curing water, the results are in agreement with those reported by other researchers such as Jalal et al. [12]. The authors indicated that the amounts of pores are decreased by the addition of nanoparticles in the mixture, which in turn led to an increased density and improved pore structure.
As illustrated in Figs. 3 and 4, the curing of concrete in colloidal nano-SiO2, which has less permeation in comparison to those cured in plain water, causes a larger drop in permeation values. In other words, nano-SiO2 curing causes the concrete with lower permeation to show a lower enhancement in permeation percent as well. However, as shown in Fig. 3, there is no correlation between the enhancement factor of permeability and nano silica percentage. On the other hand, one of the most significant findings is that basic properties of concrete have effects on the enhancement factor of permeability. The percentage of nano silica; however, has no sensible effect on the permeability.
In order to provide a more comprehensive assessment of the experiments in phase 2, ten cement samples were chosen from five commercial companies. Each sample was divided into six models with the size of 15 cm, and then 3 models of each sample were tested in plain water, while the rest were tested in water with 5% of colloidal nano-SiO2 added in. The permeability values for samples sprayed with different amounts of nanosilicon during 2 different times are given in Table 6. The average permeation depth for both control and sprayed specimens are presented in the table. With regards to EF, it can be seen from Table 6 that the maximum values of 12%, 7.5%, and 7% were obtained by spraying 50% nanosilicon for A, B and D mixtures, respectively. Moreover, EF values increase with time. This is due to more cement hydration occurring through the mixtures. Consequently, by spraying nanosilicon, nanoparticles not only act as activators to accelerate cement hydration with the assistance of their high free energy, but they can also act as kernels in cement paste, which cause a reduction in the size of Ca(OH)2
crystals and make the tropism more haphazard [32,42]. Consequently, the surface capillary pores and voids become filled.

sections.heading: 3.5. Abrasion resistance
sections.text:
The abrasion test was conducted in accordance with ASTM C 1138 [43] and measured in terms of the depth of wear at the 28th day. The abrasion resistance resulting from the specimens cured in colloidal nano-SiO2 at the 28th day are given in Table 7. It shows that the abrasion resistance of concrete samples cured in the nano-SiO2 environment has been considerably improved. EF values indicated that the enhanced extent of the abrasion resistance of the concrete samples cured in colloidal nano-SiO2 is much greater than that of concrete specimens cured in pure water. In other words, maximum and minimum values of EF obtained in the environment with 12% and 4% nano-SiO2, respectively. These results also validated by the other studies in the investigation of the relationship between abrasion resistance and surface microstructure of concrete [44]. The results showed that the abrasion resistance of concrete samples was extremely dependent on the micro hardness and pore structure of the surface zone. In fact, distinguished pore structures and the hardness within a surface zone of a few millimetres are produced by various techniques. In the circumstance of the presence of nanomaterials, the crystallization is restricted. With increasing the dosages of nanoparticles, the growth of Ca(OH)2 crystals are controlled. This makes the surface of the cement matrix more compact and homogeneous. As a result, the abrasion resistance as well as the permeability are evidently improved [44].
Table 8 shows the abrasion resistance results of the specimens sprayed with nano-SiO2 at the age of 28th day and three different times. As shown in the table, the maximum value of EF with the percentage of 32 was achieved by the samples sprayed with 50% nanosilicon at time 3 (4 h after casting). Although by increasing the dosages of nanosilicon, an increase in the volume of shear wear of the sprayed samples at time 3 was observed, for the samples at time 1 (immediately after casting) and time 2 (after 1 h and 45 min) the pattern was reversed. This is due to the increased ratio of water to cement on the surface of the concrete at earlier times. This results in the surface of the concrete to be flaked and deteriorated, which is in agreement with the past studies [45]. It was indicated that the addition of nanoparticles led to an increase in the abrasion resistance of concrete. However, with increasing the dosages of nanoparticles, the enhanced extent of abrasion resistance decreased. In other words, the distance between nanoparticles reduces with increasing the dosage of nanoparticles, and consequently Ca(OH)2 crystal cannot properly grow up. This caused a reduction in the ratio of crystal to C-S-H gel and weakness in the microstructure of cement matrix [45].

sections.heading: 3.6. SEM
sections.text:
It has been observed from similar studies in the literature that nanoparticles have a great surface area to volume ratio and act as nuclei for cement phases, increasing cement hydration due to the high reactivity. [46]. Nano-SiO2 can react with calcium hydroxide (Ca (OH)2) crystals, which are arrayed in the interfacial transition zone (ITZ) between hardened cement paste and aggregates to produce C-S-H gel [14,47]. Performing an ESEM test reveals that
the microstructure of concrete with nano-SiO2 is more uniform and compact than that of normal concrete [14].
Fig. 5a and b illustrate SEMmicrographs of the samples cured in colloidal nano-SiO2 and plain water at the 28th day, respectively. Comparative SEM micrographs of the samples sprayed with nanosilicon, and those of control specimens are given in Fig. 5a and b.
As shown in Figs. 5 and 6, specimens with nanoparticles have lower capillary pores compared with the samples without nanoparticles in particular in the surface area and lower depth. The improvement in the permeability results obtained by these two nano-curing conditions is attributed to the refined microstructure of the reaction product with less interconnectivity among the pores. Samples cured in colloids nano-SiO2 and those sprayed with nanosilicon showed the more homogeneous structure and denser microstructure in comparison with the control mixes. This phenomenon can be explained by the role of nanoparticles as filler. These particles react with water in an alkali environment and then

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In this study, the test results of permeability, abrasion of concrete cured in different environment were studied. The conclusions can be summarized as follows:
Curing of concrete panels in the nano-SiO2 environment can considerably improve the concrete permeation resistance. The optimum value of permeability obtained in mixture ’A’ cured in 12% nano-SiO2 solution, as well as samples sprayed with 50% nanosilicon at time 2. The abrasion resistance of concrete is significantly enhanced with the addition of nano-particles during the curing process. It is demonstrated that the abrasion resistance increases with the growth of the dosages of nano particles in the specimens cured in colloidal nano-SiO2. However, the indices of abrasion resistance of samples sprayed at the third time are much larger than those of samples sprayed at the first or second time. A denser microstructure was observed in the SEM images of samples cured in colloidal nano-SiO2 and sprayed with nanosilica. The densification of the microstructure can be attributed to the formation of the additional C-S-H gel.

metadata.abstractText: By protecting concrete from penetration of aggressive chemicals, low permeability is one of the most important contributory factors to the concrete’s durability. In this paper the effects of nano-SiO2 particles on concrete permeability are studied through employing the technique of spraying nanosilicon and treatment in the water-diluted nano-SiO2 oxide. To this end, some mechanical and microstructure properties of concrete are investigated. The results show that the compression strength and the resistance of specimens to water penetration are significantly increased, whether in the mixtures cured in the colloidal solution or those being sprayed with nano-SiO2. The minute dimensions of these particles allow them to penetrate up to a particular depth in a concrete panel. Hence, through improvement of concrete panel nanostructures, these particles participate in the completion of the hydration process, which in turn leads to a reduction in their permeability and development of a protective layer, and therefore the increase of bulk concrete panel durability. The experiment’s outcomes also develop thorough understanding of the effects of nano-SiO2 as an additive material after preparing the concrete and during the curing process. 2017 Elsevier Ltd.
